titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. It snowed great part of the morning, so that I had no opportunity to take my usual walk— But I returned the visits of Messrs: Raimbert and Montréal, who called yesterday to see me— Mr: J. S. Smith called upon me, and we went together, and dined with Mr Six— He had his ordinary party of twelve persons, among whom an Officer, who told me he was a native of Holland, and had been acquainted with my brother, when we resided in that Country— A general Ouvaroff; an officer in the Corps of Chevaliers Gardes, but not the commander— He appears to have a taste for the fine Arts, and express’d in conversation several just and elevated sentiments of honour. In the Evening I paid a visit at the Chevalier de Bray’s; but there was none of the family at home— I returned home about 8 O’Clock, and found the Square of St: Isaac entirely cleared of the crowd— They are allowed only the day time for their amusement; and before 8 in the Evening, by the regulations of the Police, must all be dispersed.

2. I rose this morning soon after 5. O’Clock, and had therefore a longer day than usual; but it was employed almost entirely in reading newspapers— Mr: Krehmer yesterday sent me the English papers to 27. March.— Mr: Six regularly sends me now the Moniteur, and Mr: Harris the Mercure de France, the Abeille du Nord; and the Journal de Francfort. To read them all consumes much time, not very profitably— Captain Beckford was here this forenoon— I received from Count Romanzoff a circular note with two copies of the Treaty of cession from Austria to Russia, of Territory in Gallicia, in conformity to the Treaty of Peace between France and Austria, of the 14th: of last October.— One copy of the Treaty, shews singular carelessness on the part of the Imperial Printers— The 7th: and 10th: pages are printed twice over, on the same Sheet—the 8th: and 9th: pages are missing—yet it is printed at the official press of the Senate— Evening at home— Chess with Mr: Everett.

3. I have been unwell these two days, and such is my propensity to indolence, that the slightest indisposition gives me an excuse for going nothing, with which my mind is weak enough at the time to be satisfied— I therefore did little or nothing this day; though I rose between 5 and 6. in the Morning and was up untill Midnight— It snowed all the former part of the day; and last Night Fahrenheit’s thermometer stood at 22— I walk’d however before dinner, on the Quay; to the Foundery.— Met and walked part of the way with Mr: Peter Severin— After dinner I went on the Square of St: Isaac, and saw the procession of Carriages round the Square— The Imperial family usually go in this procession the Thursday afternoon of Easter-week— But this day they were prevented by the badness of the weather, and the carriages were neither very numerous nor splendid— At seven O’Clock I attended Mr: Boucher’s lecture— But as he had mislaid his minutes, and did not expect a full attendance he only commented upon the procès verbal of the former Lectures which was read by the Secretary.— It was merely the repetition of what we had heard before— Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Maclure, paid us visits this Evening.

4. I had visits this morning from Count Schenk, the Minister of the King of Wirtemberg, and from Mr: Harris.— They shortened a little my usual walk. The procession of Carriages was much more numerous and brilliant, round the square of St: Isaac; than it was yesterday, and the Imperial Carriages and family formed part of it— I did not however see it— I read part of the 5th: volume of the two French travellers; it relates to Poland, which the treat with less severity than Russia; though by no means tenderly.— Mr: Gray was quite unwell.

5. I called upon Mr: Harris this morning, and we went together to see the shows at most of the booths on the Square of St: Isaac— At the first was a dromedary and two monkeys; a dancing bear, and a couple of poor tumblers—with a man one of whose legs was deformed, and seemingly jointed like a hand and arm; for he used that foot as a hand; to eat, drink, play upon the violin, with two pair of cymbals at once, and other like performances— At the second, were only dancers on the tight rope, and tumblers; very miserable— At the third a puppet show, with a stuff’d figure dress’d up like a giant, which they send out to stalk in the Square before their barn, for the purpose of attracting company— At the fourth, which a painting on the outside of the Stall announced as the English School; there were about half-a-dozen dancing dogs, indifferently trained— The fifth was an exhibition of the Chinese Shadows—the Broken Bridge and the traditionary Song, which we used to hear at the Fairs in Holland thirty years ago— The singer was of course Russian— But his voice grated harshest discord—the Shipwreck, and the war of the fishes, was much according to the usual style— This exhibition had the most numerous attendance— The entrance at each was half a rouble for each person— All were of the lowest order of public amusements.— Mr: J. S. Smith pass’d the Evening with us— Mr: Gray continues unwell— I received letters this Evening from Mr: Pitcairn and Mr: G. Joy—

6. I had a visit this morning from Mr: Six, who told me he had concluded to remain here another year, and appears of opinion that the issue of the transactions respecting Holland is much more favourable than was to have been expected. After dinner I went out and walked in the Mall fronting the Admiralty to see the Gaschellies or procession of Carriages.
It was more numerous than any former day; as it usually is on the last of the Easter Holidays— There were three rows of Carriages, which moved round the Church of St: Isaac, and thence to the Palace Square, of which they also went the round, and then returned. I suppose there were about a thousand—most of them with four horses. The crowd of people on foot was also great; the proportion of women small— The throng was greatest about 7 O’Clock; soon after which the Carriages began to withdraw— About half past 8. they were almost dispersed, and the swings & whirling chairs and hill-sliding ceased all at once— I came home before nine— Mr: Harris pass’d the Evening with us. Mr: Gray still remains confined to his chamber. I read Massillon’s Sermon upon the festival of the Incarnation.

7. A fall of Snow, which continued almost the whole of the day, kept me untill dinner time at home— I had visits from Mr: Harris, and from Count Bussche, the Minister from Westphalia, who came with his younger brother, and presented him to me— After dinner, although the Snow had not subsided, I attended Mr: Boucher’s Lecture— Mr: Rachette the Secretary read the procés verbal of the last Lecture— Prince Lubomirsky’s letter regretting than on order to join the Army in Turkey, would deprive him of the pleasure of attending the future lectures, which had been read, was now inserted in the procés verbal, and Mr: Boucher renewed his eulogies upon a military Officer, who employed his leisure time in the study of political economy. He instanced the examples of Xenophon, of Sully, and of an officer by the name of Jobie; who has published a book upon moneys of necessity; or monies ordained for circulation in besieged places; which have sometimes delayed the surrender of a place; and sometimes even saved it from being taken.— The Lecture was upon the right of property as founded in the Law of Nature; and particularly, of property by prior occupation. The professor discuss’d some of the principles of Grotius, Puffendorf and Vattel; whom he said it was necessary to read with caution, as some important changes in the rules of Law had taken place within the last sixty years.— He also frequently cited Clairac, on the usages and customs of the Sea— After the Lecture was finished, Mr: Boucher described the method by which he had been enabled to write with great facility many books, which had been found to contain passablement de l’érudition— It was by keeping a common-place-book. Which he had done, at least these five and twenty years— I met Mr: B. Cramer at this Lecture. It was finished, about half past eight.

8. Mr: J. S. Smith sent me a couple of English newspapers of 5 and 6. April. and afterwards called, himself— I did not employ the morning so usefully as I might have done— Walked upon the Quay both before and after dinner— At the bookseller Alici’s I purchased three packs of Historical Cards containing a compendious History of Greece, of Rome, and of France— Evening at home— Chess with Mr: Smith.

9. Visit this morning from Monsieur de Laval.— I met him some weeks since at Mr: Six’s, at dinner, and enquired of him, whether there existed any Dictionary of the Slavonian language—a Question which he was then, not able to answer. This day he told me that he had made enquiries on the subject, and had met with a Slavonian, Greek and Latin Dictionary—of which however he knew only of one copy— This belonged to the Department of the Marine— It was purchased he believed in the library of the former Count Bernstorff.— He had obtained the loan of it, and when I called to see him, would shew it to me— There was also another Dictionary—Slavonian and Russian, which went by the appellation of the Church Dictionary—this might be obtained here.— It was in five volumes— I think I shall procure it, before I return to America— I walked before and after dinner— Met Count Einsiedel, as I was returning home to dinner— He told me he should now go soon; as the roads would be good— The houses of the French Ambassador, and of some others of the foreign Ministers were illuminated this Evening, it being the birth day of the Grand-Duke and Czarewitz Constantine— Evening at home.—reading—and at Chess—

10. A regular register of the breaking up of the river Neva, at St: Petersburg has been kept, from the year 1719. This is the latest day at which the ice has ever been noted as holding— The Season is therefore late this year beyond all former example— I walked morning and Evening, upon the Quay; the Streets being still very unfit for walking in them— I attended the Lecture of Mr: Boucher— The auditory was rather more numerous than usual— Count Romanzoff was there— After descanting further upon the abstract right of property, and discussing the distinction between moveable and immovable property, he finally came to his subject, maritime Law; and gave a definition of the Sea. He laid down the principle that no Nation could claim the property of the Sea, or its shores; and cited with approbation a passage of Vatel to that effect— The Lecture finished about 8.—walking afterwards I met Mr: Shreve, and Captain Donaldson— Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray dined at Mr: Meyer’s—

11. Mr: Harris brought me this morning the manuscript of the Russian work relative to the armed neutrality, which is preparing under the patronage and direction of Count Romanzoff, and which is to be published next September. It was put into his hands by Mr: Boreel, the Count’s private Secretary; to be communicated confidentially to me; with the desire of Count Romanzoff, that I would read, and make such observations upon it, as I should think proper.— Mr: Harris further told me, that a prohibition was about to issue against the importation of refined sugars; and that he expected to obtain an exception in favour of such as should be brought in American vessels— He also said that measures were now determined upon in the Council, which would raise the exchange 20. per Cent, in the course of three or four months.— Some of the Imperial Domains were to be sold; with the proceeds of which a large amount of the paper Assignations would be redeemed— Mr: J. S. Smith passed the Evening with us— I walked on the Quay, morning and Evening— The river had not yet broken up— But this Evening there were numbers of People upon the Bridge, and upon the Quay, expecting to see the first rupture of the mass of ice—

12. The ice of the river at length broke up, at two or three O’Clock this morning. This Circumstance is said to be unusual— The most ordinary time of the day, when this Event occurs is between 2. and 6. in the afternoon— From Noon untill 2. this day I walked on the Quay to the foundery— The river was entirely open, nearly to where the Bridge had been. Below that though in motion it was slowly passing, and in solid mass extending from bank to bank— About Sunset I walked again on the Quay below the Bridge— The whole passage was then clear, and several boats were crossing the river. It was about 3 in the afternoon when the guns at the fortress were fired, and the Governor pass’d in the first Boat, to announce in form the Event to the Emperor, to whom it is said he presents a glass of the water to drink, and from whom he receives a present of an hundred ducats— It is a subject of so much interest here, and its influence is so great upon the occupations and amusements, as well as upon the comforts of the People, that it furnishes a continual fund of conversation, and innumerable wagers; a fashion introduced by the English merchants, but which is very general. From this time the Summer Season is understood to commence— The nobility and wealthy merchants leave their town residences for their Country Seats; the double windows are taken from the houses, and the business of Navigation takes place of that in Sleighs— The Ladies were out this Evening almost untill dark—that is untill between ten and eleven o’clock.

13. Russian May-day— The French Ambassador invited the Ladies, Mr: Smith and me to dine at Catherinenhof, to see the procession of the Carriages— It is the custom of the Country, on the first of May, from five in the afternoon untill about nine in the Evening, for almost all the Pleasure Carriages in St: Petersburg, to go in procession from the Peterhof gate to the village of Catherinenhof about two miles out of the City.— The Ambassador had borrowed the Country Seat of Mr: Beyer, a Merchant
who transacts business for him, to give a dinner to some of his friends and procure them an opportunity to see the whole procession— Mr: Beyer’s seat is on the road to Catherinenhoff, about a quarter of a mile this side of the village.— Mrs: Adams being unwell, the Ladies did not go— I went with Mr: Smith at three O’Clock, the hour appointed for dinner. We visited before dinner the Green-houses, where we saw an abundance of flowers in bloom; a number of strawberries nearly ripe, and peaches about the size of a pigeon’s egg— Not a symptom of vegetation yet in the garden, where all the fruit-trees are still cloathed with matting. The Company consisted of the Chevalier de Bray and Mr: Lesseps with their families, General Pardo and Count Bussche with their daughters, Count St: Julien, Baron Blome and Mr: Six, Mr: Krabbe, and the Ambassador’s family—Rayneval, St: Genest, Rumigny and Lajard— The house was newly painted and as that made it necessary to keep the windows and doors open, it was uncomfortably cold— Some of the Company came late, and it was half past four when we sat down to dinner— I sat by Mr: de Bray, who told me several curious anecdotes of Count Rumford. About 6. we rose from table, and joined the procession of Carriages— The Ambassador sent an open Carriage on the ground with four elegant bay horses, and two Jockey Postillions richly dress’d— He went himself on horseback, as did Baron Blome— Blome was in his full Court Uniform. The other Ministers had handsome Carriages with drivers in their best dresses— The Carriages appeared to me much the same, as on the square of St: Isaac last Sunday— Few handsome, and no magnificent equipages— The reigning Empress was there with Six horses, and the Empress mother with eight.— I came home about eight O’Clock, completely chill’d, with a hoarse Cold and sore throat— Mr: Harris had called to see me, in the morning, and informed me of a conversation he had just had with Count Romanzoff.

14. Visit this morning from Mr: Six— He told me a number of anecdotes respecting the revolution, which placed the Emperor Alexander upon the throne— He says that he has ascertained to demonstration not only that the Emperor was in no manner accessory to the murder of his father; but that he was affected with the deepest horror at the Event— That he absolutely refused for a long time to assume the Government, to which he was finally persuaded by old Count Soltikoff, who had been his governor, and the superintendent of his education— Paul had untill within six months of his death had but one bed-chamber with his wife— But his favourite Turkish slave Kutaissoff had bred discord between them; and he had ordered the door between his chamber and the Empress to be barred— He had notice when the conspirators broke in upon him; in time to seek a retreat through this door— It was barr’d as he had ordered, and he lost his life— There was another door, between his chamber and that of his valet de chambre— The officer commanding the guard that Night, and a conspirator, that same evening locked the door, and took the key away in his pocket—justly foreseeing that the valet de-chambre, on finding the key gone, would not mention it to the Emperor, for fear of being punished for negligence in losing the key— The first plan of the conspiracy was formed by Count Panin,and Benningsen— It was communicated to the Governor of the City Count Pahlen, who engaged in it— The Zouboff’s were merely instruments— More than eighty persons were privy to the project; many of whom spoke of it with great indiscretion— At Moscow the news was expected for many days before it arrived— Pahlen himself, at a dinner a fortnight before, said to somebody, who was speaking of Paul’s strange conduct—“This will not last another fortnight; we are all too tired of it[”]— At Prince Beloselsky’s On the very Night of the deed, a person said in presence of the Prince, and all his Company; “the Emperor Paul has not four hours more to live”— And M. de Laval went home at Midnight with this notice, and was called up in less than four hours, and told that the Emperor Paul was dead— Paul himself had received some intimations of what was in agitation— He was extremely jealous, and suspicious of every body— The very morning, or day before his death, he had uttered in presence of his Mistress Princess Gargarin threats against the
Empress; the Grand-Duke Alexander, and every body, indiscriminately— Princess Gargarin was alarmed at it; and gave notice of it to General Ouvaroff; who went to Count Pahlen, one of Paul’s greatest favourites, to request he would use his influence to appease the Emperor’s mind— Pahlen let him into the secret, and prevailed upon him to join the conspiracy.— These are among the anecdotes which Mr: Six has collected respecting that Tragedy— I asked him if he had heard that Paul’s Empress, when informed of Paul’s death; after recovering from the first shock occasioned by the intelligence, said to the Officer who brought it “Eh bien! Je suis donc votre Impératrice[”]— To which the Officer answered, Madame, c’est Sa Majesté l’Empereur Alexandre qui est mon Maitre.— He said he had not; but that under the external forms of attention and affection, he knew there was no cordiality between the mother and the Son— He said she was not popular here; and at this time particularly, was blamed, for having prevented two years ago the Marriage of the Grand-Duchess Catherine, with the Emperor Napoleon— I dined this day with the Chancellor, Count Romanzoff, at a great Diplomatic dinner— There were several persons present, who were Strangers to me; among the rest, Count Gregory Razumofsky, newly appointed Minister of the Public Instruction, and Baron Stroganoff, just returned from a public mission to Spain. At dinner I sat next to Count de Maistre, the Sardinian Minister, a man of taste and letters, who told me upon some enquiries which I made, that if there was any Grammar and Dictionary of the Slavonian language extant, it must have been compiled, and published by the Propagande at Rome— The Slavonian translation of the Psalms, used here by the Church, was considered he said as a Master-piece— Many of the Clergy here believed it to be the work of St: Jerom, who was a native of Dalmatia— But it was not probable— For St: Jerom, who was so celebrated by his vulgate Translation, if he had made that of the Psalms into the Slavonian, must have mentioned it in some other of his numerous works— I came home early and attended Mr: Boucher’s Lecture— He is now thoroughly upon the subject of Maritime Law, and discuss’d the question of open and close Seas— He pronounced the Toll-duty levied by the King of Denmark at the passage of the Sound, lawful and just, as being a fund for supporting the light-houses and other objects for the preservation of vessels navigating in these Seas— But he did not succeed remarkably well in distinguishing why Denmark should levy this duty rather than Sweden; and he told me after the lecture, that he could give no satisfactory reason for it— At this Lecture I met also Mr: Boreel, Count Romanzoff’s private Secretary, who spoke to me respecting the work he is preparing upon the History of the armed neutrality, and upon which he requested my observations.

15. I had taken great pains to procure a copy of Pallas’s Flora Rossica; to send as a present to Harvard University; and by the friendly interference of Count Alexander Soltikoff, I had obtained one— I sent it two months ago to Mr: Harris’s bookbinder, to be bound; and after waiting for it, weeks after it should have been ready, it was this day sent to me, utterly ruined— Nearly a fourth part of almost every plate in the book has been paired away, in cutting off the edges, and scarcely a plant in the two volumes remains without mutilation.— Blessed are they who can bear disappointments without losing their temper— Mr: Harris called this afternoon to see me, and I shewed him what was left of the Book— He was much mortified, and desired me to send him back this fragment, undertaking to compel the book-binder to substitute a complete one in its stead— I fear this will prove impossible, and I shall have to put up with my misfortune— I went this day before dinner to the Court Bookseller Alici’s—for a preliminary advertisement to the historical Cards, which I purchased to send home to my Son George; which upon examining
the packs I found was missing— It contained the directions for using the Cards— Alici himself told me that this advertisement was missing from all the sets of the Cards that he had— But his shop-keeper found one before I came away— I was driven home from my customary walk, by a heavy flight of Snow— Evening at home; finding out with the Ladies, the riddles, logogriphes and Charades in the Mercure de France.

16. Visits this morning to Monsieur de Laval, to Count and Baron Bussche, and to Mr: Six; the last of whom only I found at home.— He accidentally mentioned to me that he had been drawing Bills upon Holland, and shewed me the minute of his Bankers; they charge him 1/2 per Cent for Commission 1/4 per Cent Brokerage; and for Stamps & Postage, about 1/8 per Cent— These, he tells me are the only charges that any Banker has ever made for transacting this sort of business, and he has drawn in favour at least of four different houses— The rate of exchange allowed him, was at 11. 1/4 stuivers to a Ruble— My very particular friends Messieurs Meyer and Brüxner, have uniformly charged me for the same business, 1. per Cent Commission 5/8 per Cent Brokerage & Stamp—and about 12 Rubles Postage— They also allow me about 1/8 of a stuiver less to a Ruble than the current exchange, and in my last draft charged me 11 3/8 stuivers to the Ruble; which Mr: Six was allowed by his Banker at 11 1/4.— Thus the special friendship and kindness of Messrs: Meyer & Brüxner, costs me nearly 3 per Cent upon the amount of all my drafts, while Mr: Six gets his negotiated for about one. Morning and Evening walks upon the quay— Mr: Everett & Mr: Gray went to a Ball, at a Mr: Zenowieff’s— Mr: J. S. Smith pass’d part of the Evening with us— There is now a strong twilight at Midnight.

17. I was engaged great part of the morning in learning Russian— Walked to the Summer Gardens before dinner— They are now open; since the first of May, Old Stile; but are not yet pleasant for walks— Mr: Smith dined at Mr: Meyer’s. In the Evening I attended Mr: Boucher’s Lecture— He noticed the question I had put to him, why Denmark should levy a duty upon the passage of vessels through the Sound, and not Sweden, to which he gave what he thought a sufficient answer.— That is, that the channel is on the Danish side. He said he had taken great pains to trace the origin of this duty, but had not succeeded in ascertaining it— His Lecture this Evening was upon Shores—Alluvion—and attérrisement, which he said should not be confounded together— The first was gradual, the last the effect of some sudden & extraordinary change— He mentioned a very singular and celebrated law-suit which had been decided not long since in the kingdom of Naples arising from an event of this kind— An Earthquake, had transported one man’s house upon the territory of another— And the question was to whom the house then belonged— The first tribunal decided in favour of the first proprietor; but upon the appeal the Superior Court reversed this decision and gave the house to the owner of the land where it had fallen— Very justly, said Mr: Boucher, because it is an invariable maxim that the accessory follows the principal— Now the house was the accessory to the land, and not the land to the house— As if Earthquakes respected maxims of Law; or as if maxims of Law, were made to meet the contingencies of Earthquakes— The natural Justice of particular cases is very often at variance with the general maxims of Law; and this with submission to Mr: Boucher, appears to be one of them.— At the Lecture I met the Chevalier de Berks; Secretary to Count St: Julien— The storm prevented me from walking afterwards—

18. Mr: Martin called on me this forenoon, to make enquiries respecting Mr: Cutts’s affair; upon which I gave him such information as I have. Walking upon the Quay, I met the Emperor, who stop’d, and enquired, whether I had received any news from America— I told him, I had none direct, for several months; but I hoped I should have
soon, now that the river and Gulph were open— Particularly, as I had heard that several American vessels coming here, had already pass’d the Sound— He said he had heard the same thing— I afterwards met, and walked some time with General Pardo, who appears to be in high Spirits— He says the French have been severely beaten in Spain, and that they will yet have a very bloody War to wage— I dined with Mr: Six, and one of his ordinary Companies of ten or twelve persons—Chevalier de Bray and Count Lüxbourg—Mr: Brancia—St: Genest—Lesseps—A Polish General, whom Mr: Six introduced to me, but whose name I could not catch—& Mr: Soldan, the dutch Officer in Russian Service, who knew my brother at the Hague— After dinner the company sat down to Trictrac & Cards; and I took my walk on the short quay of the Neva—

19. Mr: Harris paid me a visit, and introduced to me a Mr: Heard of Boston, who arrived two days since from Constantinople. A Place to which some Americans have at last obtained access, and he is very anxious that a Treaty of Commerce should be obtained between the United States and the Porte— The Swedish Chargé d’Affaires there he says has hitherto protected the Americans. He gave me a letter from the Swedish Chargé d’Affaires there to Count Stedingk— Walking on the Admiralty Mall, I met the Emperor who stop’d and made some observations about the weather— He said I should have a bad opinion of the climate here, and that eight months was too long for the winter to last.— I dined with Monsieur de Laval— The ladies were invited, but Mrs: Adams was not well enough to go— General Betancourt and his family were there— Count Severin Potocki, Count de Maistre, and Baron Rechberg— Mr: Harris & Mr: J. S. Smith— Mr: de Laval who was formerly Duke de Laval-Montmorenci, first came here as Cavalier d’Ambassade to M. de Ségur— But his family being proscribed, and his property confiscated during the Revolution, he remained here, and married a Princess Kazitsky, of one of the wealthiest families in Russia— He is a man of taste and literature. He shewed me some of his pictures— A small knife-grinder of Teniers for which he gave this day 400 ducats— His belle-Ferroniere— La Joconde of Leonardo da Vinci cost him 10,000 Roubles— He has a Youth and Courtezan, said to be of Georgione—doubtful, but excellent— A Roman Charity of Guercino— Not a pleasing picture— Indeed this subject, though a favourite one of the Painters has always something disgusting to me. A starving old man, sucking at the breast of a young woman, has something so unnatural to the sense as well as to the Fancy, that it requires a knowledge of the Story, to reconcile it to the mind— There is great moral beauty in the fact; but nothing cheering, in its representation to the eye— M. de Laval has also a small antique Bronze bust, with the name of Plato on the back— But Count de Maistre insisted upon it that it was not Plato, and remarked that the P. of the name was in the latin character, while the other letters were Greek— I saw also the Slavonian, Greek, and Latin Dictionary and took down the title page— At dinner I sat next to Count Severin Potocki, and had much conversation with him. In the Evening I went to the German Play where I found the Ladies and saw an Opera in German called the Cure for wives—said to be from the Italian Poche ma Buone— I saw it at Dresden under the title of Le Donne cambiate— In English ’tis called the Devil to pay— The music is charming, but we had not half of it— Count Luxbourg pass’d an hour with us at the close of the Evening.

20. Visits from Mr: Harris this Morning, and from Mr: J. S. Smith, in the Evening— Detained at home untill 4. O’Clock. Then took a short walk, and again in the Evening— I met and walked with General Pardo, who continues to be in high Spirits— He thinks the Emperor Napoleon is going to adopt king Ferdinand as his son; but he says Ferdinand will never be suffered to enter Spain afterwards— He spoke with great contempt of Ferdinand’s character, whose name he said was only used by the Patriots as matter of form; and that, if it was found necessary the mask would soon be drop’d.
He said that he should have advised the king of England against the measure, of sending the brave man, who had fallen into the French Emperor’s power, and who would at least be treated as a prisoner of War— He should have told him, (the king) you think, you are sending for a Man— But you will not find one— I know him— You will find nothing but a cowardly and pusillanimous being (un être lâche et pusillanime) who will be the first to betray you— The General added that if Napoleon should adopt Ferdinand, he supposed that he himself should have to give a Fête. But now, on the Austrian marriage, he should illuminate his house, and leave Caulincourt to give the fête— It is to be a great Ball, next Wednesday. The Ambassador he told me had received this day two Couriers— One was Mr: Prevost, who has been long expected, and the other from Antwerp, with an account of the Emperor Napoleon’s visit with the Empress at that place— I read Massillon’s Sermon upon the Resurrection, which I think inferior to many of the others, and hardly worthy of the subject.

21. Visit this morning from Mr: Six. Political, literary, and speculative conversation with him— He has not so much learning as General Pardo, but he is very familiar with Horace and Virgil— He is a good-tempered man, and has more of moral sense, than almost any man I have met in Europe— I paid visits to Count Stedingk, and Count St: Julien— Stedingk told me he did not know now when he should go home; but he hoped not to go through Finland, for he could not bear the thought of that Country— (He signed the Treaty which ceded it to Russia.) St: Julien asked me many questions about America; and told me how much the new French Empress was admired in France, for her beauty— Most especially for her foot, which I suppose is like the foot of Queen Genevra— The Count also talked of the War in Turkey, a subject which he appears to understand very well— He is more of a soldier than a Courtier; but he has a taste for jewelry and skill in the learning of precious stones. In the Evening I attended Mr: Boucher’s lectures, which was upon islands—wrecks of the sea, and treasure trove— Some others of his auditors as well as myself, had hesitated to join in his approbation of the Neapolitan tribunal for giving the house of one man to another, because an earthquake had transported it upon his land— He defended his doctrine by the usual argument that Courts of Justice must decide questions upon general principles and not upon particular contingencies— The latter kind of Sentences he said were called Rustic Judgments (Jugemens rustiques) and they were condemned by all enlightened Jurists— He had got a long story about my question to him, and its answer, in his procès verbal.

22. Visits this morning successively from Captain Donaldson and Mr: Plumer, and from Mr: Graham, who intends to sail for America, as soon as the Navigation is free. The ice still remains unmoved part of the way between Cronstadt and this place; and in the gulph below— The Canal before our windows is this day clear of ice, for the first time, and the little ferry boat plies again between its sides— This was a beautiful, clear, Spring-day— The thermometer in the shade at 60.— I walked as usual morning and Evening— The latter part of which Mr: J. S. Smith passed with us.

23. There is a custom of visiting annually the fortress of St: Petersburg this day, the occasion of which I have not heard. I thought I had not the time to spare and did not go— Mr: Harris called upon me this afternoon; and told me he was informed that General Armstrong had left Paris.— The French Ambassador gave this Evening a splendid Ball, on occasion of the illumination marriage of the Emperor Napoleon— It was attended by the Emperor, and Imperial family. The Hotel was elegantly illuminated, as were those of General Pardo, Count Bussche—Mr: Six—the Chevalier de Bray, and Mr: Brancia, the Chargé d’Affaires of Naples.— As the imperial family were at the Ball, it was necessary to go early— We went at 9 O’Clock, but it was day-light as at noon, so that the illumination made scarcely any show at-all— It was past two in the morning when the Court retired, after which we immediately came home— It was then again broad-day-light, and by the time I got to bed, almost Sun-rise. At midnight it scarcely could be called dark. The Emperor was
gracious to every body, even beyond his usual custom, which is remarkable for affability— He asked Mr: Harris to shew him where Mrs: Adams sat, and danced a Polonaise with her; and afterwards one with Catherine Johnson, a Circumstance the more noticed, as she has not been presented at Court— He enquired of me whether I had taken a walk this day, and on my answering that I had, he observed that he had not met me— He said that the difference of my looks in the Street, without a wig, from that in which he had usually seen me, had been the cause that the first time he had met me he did not recognize me— He told me the occasion upon which he had commenced the practice of walking daily— It was recommended to him to strengthen his foot, which had received a hurt last Summer, by the oversetting of his droshky.— And although he preferr’d riding on horse-back, he believed walking was the healthiest of all exercise. The Prince of Wirtemberg, the brother of the Empress Mother entered also into conversation with me, though I had never been presented to him— The Rooms were excessively warm, and a very small part of the company took real pleasure in the fête.— I heard the Ambassador himself say to some one, that he gave this Ball, because he was obliged to do it— It gave him no pleasure— I spoke to Count Bussche, about his illumination— Ay! said he— I promise you, I am well paid for my illumination— I asked General Pardo, if as a good Catholic, he did not expect to have some atonement to make hereafter for the vain and excessive enjoyments of this Night— Nay, said he— But I hope what I experience this Night, will expiate some of my Sins— Count St: Julien, told me of a speech made by the old Prince de Ligne upon this marriage, not fit to be repeated— I had some conversation at supper, with a nobleman whose name I have not yet learnt, upon the Russian and Slavonian languages.

24. I did not rise untill past ten this morning— There was a constant rain almost the whole day— I attempted a walk before dinner, but was obliged to return, after walking not more than a quarter of a mile— In the Evening, I went with Mr: Everett, and attended Mr: Boucher’s Lecture; which was upon Wrecks of the Sea & Strays— But it was very short— The time was principally occupied in the reading and commenting upon the procés verbal of the last Lecture— And in some reflections upon the questions which Monsieur le Conseiller d’Etat had received in an anonymous letter, from a very learned, polite and modest person, of which he should take more notice hereafter— There was more agitation of the question regarding the Neapolitan judgment upon the transported house. A gentleman had enquired how it would be, if a whole City should be thus transported— A very perplexing question to Monsieur le Professeur, who could only suggest that the principle of lésion d’outre moitié, by which according to the civil law, a man may redeem on equitable terms whatever he has sold for less than half its worth, might rescue the City, from the possession of its new proprietor— The lecture closed about half past eight— We amused the remainder of the Evening with Cards, & Chess— Baron Schladen, the Prussian Minister called upon me this morning— I had told him last Evening, that I wished to have a little conversation with him, and would call some morning at his house. I read to him the passage from Mr: Pitcairn’s letter, upon which I had desired to see him— The object is to endeavour to obtain a remission of part of the duties in the Ports of Prussia, upon articles imported, which are to be sent into the dominions of other Sovereigns— They make the transit duty, equal to that upon consumption— The Baron said that he would write to the Minister of Finance upon the subject, and give him an account of our conversation; but he said that the necessity of raising by any means whatsoever money, to pay the arrears of contributions
to the French, was such, that the diminution of duties was the most improbable thing in the world to be obtained— Every distant or secondary consideration must be forgotten or sacrificed to that— The duties and taxes in every shape, and upon every Class of the People, were oppressive beyond all conception— They had among others an income tax of eight per Cent upon every individual in the kingdom, which might be repeated three times in a year— In short such was the desperation of their Affairs, that any reasoning upon probable or contingent benefits, at any future period could scarcely be expected to obtain a hearing— I urged it to him as an argument of direct and immediate interest; on the ground that a moderate transit duty, would produce more revenue, than one which should nearly amount to a prohibition— He appeared readily to accede to this opinion, but not to entertain the Expectation that it would be adopted by his Government.

25. Mr: J. S. Smith called upon me this morning, and brought me some French and a German London Newspapers— Mr: Harris and Mr: Maclure pass’d the Evening with us— I walked before dinner, and in the Evening— But the Streets are again made so unpleasant for walking, by the heavy rains that my walks were confined to the quays— The ice on the gulph of Finland, between St: Petersburg and Cronstadt has not been broken up until yesterday.

26. Captain Norman was here this morning; and brought me a letter from Mr: Bourne, at Amsterdam— I walked on the Neva quay to the Fontanka; thence up to the Newsky Perspective; down that to the Moika Canal on which we live; and home— It is a walk of just an hour and a half— I took a shorter walk in the Evening— We were up untill nearly one in the morning— As there is no darkness at present, there seems to be no distinction of hours, which invite to retirement.

27. I have been troubled with a severe cold and cough, ever since the ride of the Russian May-day, and the dinner at Catharinenhoff— It waked me this morning, when I had been scarcely four hours in bed— I rose and found the Sun, about an hour above the horizon; but it was little after 4. O’Clock— On trying a short nap, further, I found it on waking again, nearly ten— We rise late of course, and I find the mornings very short— I walk’d only to the Winter Palace, and saw the river full of the ice, floating down from the Lake Ladoga— I dined with Count Stedingk, and arriving late, found his company at dinner when I arrived— Had a game of Chess with him after dinner— He had received a Courier from Stockholm this morning, and expects the frigate which is to carry him home, in a fortnight at Cronstadt; orders having been already expedited to Carlscrona, for her, to sail— His successor, he told me was not yet appointed. It would probably be General Skiöldebrand, but whether he would accept the appointment was uncertain. He had written to him (Count Stedingk) to enquire what he ought to insist upon as a Salary, if he should come—to which the answer would be, the advice not to come at a Salary under twenty thousand rix dollars banco—at two Rix dollars to a ducat— Upon this at the present favourable course of exchange, he could live decently; and not upon less— But whether the Government would give so much was questionable—and on other terms the General would probably not come. I asked him what his own Salary as Ambassador had been— He said it was thirty thousand Rix dollars, besides a Pension of three thousand, which he received in his military capacity— He still now received the same Salary.— This is large; but Mr: Rumigny the Secretary of the French Ambassador told Mr: Harris, about two months ago, that he had just closed the accounts of the Ambassador’s expences, for the year 1809—and that they exceeded one million and fifty thousand Roubles— The preceding year 1808. they had also amounted to more than a million— From Count Stedingk’s I went, and paid visits to the French Ambassador, to the Chevalier & Madame de Bray; and to Monsieur and Madame de Laval, none of whom were at home— At Mr: Krehmer’s I was received— He has been for some weeks very ill—part of the time, dangerously so— But is now recovering— The Baron de Blome, Mr: de Krabbe, and
some other company was there— I came home about 9. in the Evening— Mr: Smith and Mr: Everett, who had been out to dine at Mr: Venning’s Country Seat, came home about an hour after— I read this day Massillon’s Sermon, upon the day of Pentecost— A contrasted parallel between the Spirit of the World, and the Spirit of Christ.

28. Mr: Krehmer told me last Evening, that three American vessels had arrived the day before, at Cronstadt— Mr: Harris called upon me this morning, and gave me the same information— The Chevalier and Madame de Bray paid a visit to us this forenoon— They are going into the Country; to pass the Summer, and next Winter if he can obtain the permission from his Court, to travel into France and Italy— He assigns for this several motives— The real one I suppose to be to escape from the overwhelming expence, at which they are obliged to live here— Madame de Bray, is to go the day after to-morrow— The Chevalier follows her, next week— They pass the Summer at the house of her father Mr: de Löwenstern in Livonia. I visited some Russian book-stalls; but made no purchases— In the Evening, I attended Mr: Boucher’s Lecture— It was almost wholly engross’d in reading over again the Chapter, upon Epaves—the anonymous letter upon it; which I perceived by its Contents was written by Mr: Lamolignière— And Mr: Boucher’s answer, which was very long— He had afterwards one short chapter upon Treaties of Commerce— Mrs: Adams and Catherine pass’d the Evening at Mrs: Krehmer’s— The weather was warm; and in the Evening there was sharp lightening; with little thunder, and much rain.

29. I had a visit this morning from Mr: Six, who brought me three small packets to be sent by the first vessels going to America— He has received letters from his agents there, respecting his Estates, which are highly satisfactory.— Received a Packet of American Newspapers, forwarded by the Editors of the New-England Palladium. They come no later than to the 27th: of February— I visited again some Russian Book-stalls, and purchased a few books— It shortened my walk to the length of about one hour. In the Evening we had Cards— Count Einsiedel at last took his departure this Evening.

30. There was a severe Storm of wind and rain last Evening, which obliged Count Einsiedel to return, for the Night— He finally left the City this morning— We shall now remove to the House and Apartments which were occupied by him— I had a visit this forenoon from Count Bussche, the Westphalian Minister— The Ladies went, and examined the apartments in which we are to reside— My occupations at home detained me from going— Mr: Plumer spent the Evening with us.

31. I went this morning, and looked over the Apartments where we are to take our future residence— They are small and inconvenient, though to be paid at a very high price— We cannot go into them untill the next week. This business employed me however all the morning— In the Evening, I attended Mr: Boucher’s Lecture. It consisted entirely of a Commentary on the Notice in the procès verbal, of Mr: Lamolignière’s anonymous letter, and a retorted attack both upon the language and the legal doctrines of this letter—and of a reply to another letter of the Chevalier de Reiberti—questioning the correctness of the Neapolitan decision, upon the Territory transported by an Earthquake— There was no time left for the Lecture; which of course was postponed untill next Monday.— Mr: Harris pass’d the Evening with us; and I settled the account of his advances for me, which he furnished me this day.

Day. I rise very irregularly from 6. to 9. O’Clock— Read 5 Chapters in the Bible, and any other casual subject of attention untill breakfast about 10— Study the Russian Alphabet and Grammar two hours after breakfast. Write or receive visitors untill 3 or 4. Walk untill 5. Dine— Read or write an hour after dinner— Walk, another hour— Evening with visitors, or at Chess or Cards untill twelve— At which hour with a strong remnant of twilight we retire to bed. A pressure of occupation makes me postpone monthly reflections for the present.
